name: balaenoptera-acutorostrata
definition: The common minke whale is a species of minke whale within the suborder of baleen whales.
description:
Common minke whales are one of the smallest baleen whales, second smallest only to the Pygmy right whale.

Females are larger than males.

They have a dark gray back and clean white underbelly.

The jaw is dark gray on both sides.

Common minke whales have about 230 to 360 pairs of creamy white baleen plates with a fine white fringe.

The tail of these whales extends into two long tips and the dorsal fin is high and curved back.

Common minke whales are found in all oceans and some adjoining seas.

The migration patterns of these whales are poorly known.

Common minke whales prefer cooler regions.

They occur in both coastal and offshore waters.

They also often enter bays, estuaries, lagoons and fjords.

Like all baleens, Common minke whales are carnivorous.

They feed on krill and some small fish.

Their diet also includes pelagic crustaceans and cephalopods and varies by region, season, and year.

The whales fed at an average depth of 19 meters, reaching a maximum depth of 106 meters.

Dives averaged 1.5 minutes, and a maximum of 9.4 minutes.

The main predators of the minke whale are the transient killer whales and sharks.

Little is known about the reproductive behavior of Common minke whales.

Females are known to be promiscuous, suggesting that these minke whales exhibit polygynandrous (promiscuous) mating system.

Females have young every other year.

Gestation period lasts 10 to 11 months after which a single calf is born.

The calf is weaned after a period of 5 months.

Common minke whales become reproductively mature at about 6 to 8 years of age for females and about 6 to 7 years for males.

Common minke whales are usually seen singly or in small groups of 2 to 4 individuals.

Where food is abundant they can be seen in large aggregations in the 100s.

These whales are curious creatures.

They often approach ships and wharfs which is not typical for whales of their family.

They are also highly acrobatic.

They can leap completely out of the water like dolphins.

Common minke whales are fast swimmers.

Some of their populations are migratory.

Both southern and northern populations often spend winter in tropical waters, although at different times of year.

This happenes because of seasonal differences in their homelands.

Although first ignored by whalers due to its small size and low oil yield, it began to be exploited by various countries beginning in the early 20th century.

As other species declined, larger numbers of common minke whales were caught, largely for their meat.

It is now one of the primary targets of the whaling industry.

facts.name: Minke whales is a filter feeder
facts.value: Minke whales feed by filtering food out of the ingested water using baleen plates.

facts.name: Two blowholes on the head
facts.value: Minke whales have two blowholes on the head. V-shaped exhaled condensed air can reach 2 meters in height.

facts.name: Very curious creatures
facts.value: Minke whales are very curious creatures. They like to swim around ships and to observe people.

facts.name: Can dive 20 to 25 minutes
facts.value: Minke whales can dive 20 to 25 minutes, but they usually spend 10 to 12 minutes under the water before returning to the surface to breathe.

facts.name: Dorsal side is dark grey
facts.value: Dorsal side of the body is dark grey or black in color. Underside of the body is white. Some species have white patches on the flippers.

facts.name: Natural enemies
facts.value: Besides humans, natural enemies of minke whales are killer whales.

facts.name: Females reproduce every second year
facts.value: Females reproduce every second year. Pregnancy lasts 10 to 11 months and ends with one calf. Baby is 2.7 meters long and has 450 kilograms at birth. It depends on the mother's milk during the first 5 months of its life.

facts.name: Diet consists mainly of krill
facts.value: Diet of minke whales consists of krill (small crustaceans), fish like herring and sardines, and squids.

facts.name: Fast and agile swimmers
facts.value: Minke whales are fast and agile swimmers. They can swim at the speed of 38 kilometers per hour when they are threatened. During the feeding time, minke whales swim very slow, only 2 to 11 kilometers per hour.

facts.name: Minke whales produce loud songs
facts.value: Minke whales produce loud songs (150 decibels) that can be heard couple of kilometers away. Songs are used for communication. Songs can be heard during the mating season, migration or when they need to inform other whales about upcoming danger.

facts.name: Minke whales are solitary creatures
facts.value: Minke whales are usually solitary creatures. They occasionally swim in groups (pods) composed of 2 to 4 animals. Minke whales gather during the mating season which takes place during the summer.

facts.name: Torpedo-shaped body
facts.value: Minke whale has torpedo-shaped body and two long flippers. Dorsal fin is short and hooked. Area near the tail is covered with series of ridges.

facts.name: Between 260 and 360 baleen plates
facts.value: Minke whales have between 260 to 360 baleen plates in their mouth. Baleen plates are yellow and usually 30 centimeters long.

facts.name: Survive up to 50 years in the wild
facts.value: Minke whales can survive up to 50 years in the wild.

facts.name: Is a smal whale
facts.value: Minke whales are one of the smallest species of whales. They can reach 6.7 to 7.3 meters in length and up to 14 tons of weight. Females are slightly larger than males.

related.definition: The blue whale  is a marine mammal belonging to the baleen whale parvorder, Mysticeti.
The killer whale or orca  is a toothed whale belonging to the oceanic dolphin family, of which it is the largest member.
The short-finned pilot whale is one of the two species of cetaceans in the genus Globicephala, which it shares with the long-finned pilot whale.
The beluga whale   is an Arctic and sub-Arctic cetacean.
The fin whale , also known as finback whale or common rorqual and formerly known as herring whale or razorback whale, is a cetacean belonging to the parvorder of baleen whales.
Cuvier's beaked whale is the most widely distributed of all the beaked whales.
The narwhal is a medium-sized toothed whale that possesses a large tusk from a protruding canine tooth.
